name: Browserstack
description:
Saas based web & mobile testing platform that allows developers to test across browsers, operating systems & real-life mobile devices. This has been a staple of our cross-browser testing strategy for some time and is used on many projects.

Browserstack website.

name: Rollup
description:
Rollup is a module bundler for JavaScript which compiles small pieces of code into something larger and more complex, such as a library or application.

It uses the new standardized format for code modules included in the ES6 revision of JavaScript, instead of previous idiosyncratic solutions such as CommonJS and AMD.

Rollup website.

name: Iron-session
description:
Node.js stateless session utility using signed and encrypted cookies to store data. Works with Next.js, Express, and Node.js HTTP servers.

The session data is stored in encrypted cookies (seals). And only your server can decode the session data. There are no session ids, making iron sessions stateless from the server point of view.

Iron-session GitHub repo.

name: MSW
description:
Mock Service Worker - Intercept & mock requests at the network level via service workers.

We use this to make mocking of network requests easier in our unit tests.

MSW website.

name: Commitizen
description:
We use Commitizen to define and enforce a set of rules for committing code to our projects.

We use the Commitizen CLI to simplify the creation of commit messages and manage the versioning of releases based on those commits.

Commitizen website.

name: nvm
description:
Version manager for NodeJS.

This allows us to install multiple versions of Node on a machine.

We use an .nvmconfig file to force specific versions of Node when a project requires it.

nvm GitHub repo.

name: Lighthouse
description:
Chrome web browser plugin for analysing a web page to assess it's performance, quality, and correctness.

We use this tool as part of our exploratory testing and in our pipelines to ensure that the quality of a code deployment hasn't negatively impacted on the web app.

Plugin on the Chrome web store.

name: Storybook
description:
Tool for building, testing and documenting UI components in isolation.

We have found success using Storybook to enable us to practice Visual Test-Driven Development (VTDD)

Storybook website.

name: Nx
description:
A devtool for managing monorepos. It provides performance benefits via it's computation cache, dependency graph & affected commands meaning that it only rebuilds / tests apps or libs based on recent changes.

Nx website.

name: Browserify
description:
Javascript Module Bundler.

Browserify website.

name: Supertest
description: Superagent driven abstraction for testing HTTP calls

name: Concurrently
description:
Tool to allow multiple commands to be run concurrently.

Concurrently Github repo.

name: StyleLint
description:
A linter for enforcing CSS styles and conventions, as well as enforce non-stylistic conventions.

StyleLint website

name: JAWS
description: A screen reader for Windows that can be used to test web content for accessibility. Some information on how to use it can be found on webAIM here

name: Google Optimise360
description:
Optimisation, Insights, User Journey Testing & Personalisation tool from Google. Designed to work seamlessly with other Google solutions such as Analytics, Ads & Cloud.

Website

name: Launch Darkly
description:
Feature management suite allowing easy and fast switching of feature flags. Can be used to launch features behind flags and toggle on and off according to release schedule, with flag switching taking under 1s. Has a native JavaScript SDK to optimise management of flags locally.

Launch Darkly website.

name: Detox
description:
Gray box end-to-end testing and automation framework for React Native apps.

Detox website.

name: Postman
description:
Platform to help design, test & modify apis.

Postman website.

name: Storyshots
description:
Adds automatic Jest snapshot testing for Storybook.

Storyshot website

name: Parcel
description:
Relatively new build tool promising fast builds of web projects (10-20x faster than other JS build tools according to reported figures). Built in Rust. Supports multi-core, parallelised builds which are cached by Parcel. Supports building files on demand.

Parcel website

name: Vitest
description:
Unit testing framework powered by Vite.

Vitest website

name: Tailwind
description:
Utility first css framework.

Tailwind website.

name: TDD
description: Software development methodology focusing on testing prior to feature development (Related to a concept known as Test First). Follows a 'Red'-'Green'-'Refactor' cadence whereby a minimum requirement is tested before functionality is written, minimum possible functionality is written to pass the test, and the resulting code is refactored using the passed test as a benchmark for success. More info.

name: Four Key Metrics
description: TBC

name: Serverless
description: Broad suite of technologies provided by AWS to facilitate the deployment of applications without the need for running a central server. Including stateless function computation, Event management, API gateway, Data storage and more. Serverless architecture can be managed and deployed using Terraform. More info

name: Code / Deploy On The Edge
description: TBC

name: Functional Programming
description: A programming paradigm whereby programs are produced by the composition and application of functions. Functions are first class citizens in JavaScript and many functional programming concepts are either already part of the language or are in proposal stage (e.g. the Pipe operator. The React framework has been moving in a functional direction for some time, with function components now being the recommended approach.

name: Monads
description: TBC

name: Blue Green Deployments
description: An application release strategy that gradually moves the flow of traffic from one (blue) version of an app or service to another (green) using a load balancer, subject to satisfactory performance with the aim of deprecating and removing the blue environment. Can be facilitated with tools such as LaunchDarkly or Google Optimise360. More info. Similar to Canary Deployments

name: Canary Deployments
description: An application release strategy that deploys an update to a small subset of servers and nodes to check the integrity of a release, before rolling the update out to all servers or nodes once satisfied. More info. Similar to Blue Green Deployments

name: Single-Piece Flow
description: TBC

name: Pair Programming
description: A software development technique where two programmers work together in order to develop a feature. One programmer takes the role of Driver to write code and another reviews the code as it is typed in. Facilitates communication and knowledge-sharing within teams and produces better resulting code due to on-the-fly peer review. Facilitated remotely using telecommunication software, and it is also possible to collaborate in an environment remotely, for example using Microsoft Live Share. More info

name: Mob Programming
description: A software development technique where a whole team will work on the same problem. Similar to Pair Programming. Can be used for programming tasks as well as defining and estimating user stories, designing and testing. More info

name: Theming
description: TBC

name: Feature Toggling
description: Software development and release technique that uses conditions to enable or disable features at runtime. Facilitates more frequent releases by allowing for more flexibility with deployed code and allowing features to be switched on and off without redeployment. Can be facilitated with tools such as LaunchDarkly

name: A/B Testing
description: Otherwise known as split testing. Uses a load balancer to deliver one of several (usually two) versions of a resource to a user. The analytics from these groupings can then be compared using other tools to determine if a change has had an intended effect (e.g. an increased sales conversion rate). More info.

name: Bit
description: An open source toolchain for component-driven software. Facilitates the connection of modular software components. Use cases include Design systems, Micro frontends, Monorepos and Microservices. More info

name: Vercel
description: A platform offering a number of services for developing, previewing and shipping frontend work, including Frontend infrastructure, Edge functions, Analytics, a CLI, CI and their flagship frontend product Next.js. More info

name: S3 Bucket
description: AWS hosted cloud storage. Offers the ability to store data for virtually any use case, with multiple types of storage ranging from fast ready-access to deep 'glacier' backup storage. Marketing materials quote exabyte-scale storage for single companies. More info.

name: Cloudflare CDN
description: Global content delivery network with extensive worldwide network. Highly programmable with dynamic caching. Offers multiple pricing options according to scale of business. More Info

name: Docker
description: A software platform that allows for quick building, testing and deployment of applications. Docker packages software into containers that allow for software to be self-contained, with all dependencies necessary to deploy that software on any supported environment, a process known as 'containerisation'. Docker containers can be hosted on cloud environments including AWS, Azure and Google Cloud. More info.

name: Azure Application Insights
description: Platform to collect, analyse and view telemetry data from cloud environments. Offers a suite of tools for using telemetry including curated insights, logging, critical situation alerts, troubleshooting data and detailed visualisations of telemetry data. More info

name: Azure App Configuration
description: Azure service to centrally manage application settings and feature flags. Useful for storing all application settings to be served to multiple services and products. More info

name: Azure DevOps
description: A suite of tools from Microsoft including repos, pipelines, agile boards, test plans, CI/CD and more. A one-stop-shop for all things DevOps from Microsoft. More info.

name: Amplience
description: API-first headless CMS designed for enterprise retail. More info.

name: Azure Frontdoor
description: Azure provided CDN providing global access to resources. Scales using Microsoft's network, including edge support. Highly configurable. More info.

name: Blob-Storage
description: Scalable and secure cloud storage for objects. Facilitates the creation of Data Lakes. Flexible costings. Part of Microsoft's Azure suite of cloud tools. More info.

name: Plyr
description: A simple, lightweight and accessible HTML5 video player. More info.

name: Enzyme
description: A testing utility for react that allows you to test React component output. Testing of output is quite imperative. Has largely been retired in favour of tools such as Testing-Library. More info.

name: GraphQL
description: A query language for APIs and a runtime for fulfilling queries with existing data. Allows the building of hierarchies within the API and selective querying of data by the client. Multiple GraphQL frontend tools exist, including Apollo and Relay, which can offer features to streamline, componentise and optimise data fetching throughout an application. An alternative to REST. More info.

name: Turborepo
description: A 'high-performance' build system for JavaScript and TypeScript codebases. Features incremental builds, parallel builds, content-aware hashing and remote caching for CI/CD pipelines. Supports monorepos. Part of the 'Turbo Build' suite of products. More info.

name: MaterialUI 5
description: A widely used, 'fully-loaded' component library for react which offers fully-featured components that implement Google's Material Design principles. Components are customisable and offer their own APIs. Part of the MUI React UI Tools platform. More info.

name: Webpack Federated Modules
description: Used to build and maintain frontend modules separately, which can be composed together to form a finished product. Separate builds act like containers which can be used and consumed by other containers. Often known as 'Micro-Frontends'. More info.

name: govuk-frontend
description: A set of tools used to build UI for government platforms and services. Maintained by the Government Digital Service. Extremely useful for complying with Government requirements. More info.

name: Native Base
description: An accessible, utility-first component library for consistent UI across React and React Native. More info.

name: SWR
description: React hooks library for data fetching using the stale while revalidate caching strategy. Allows for more effective management of async data fetching within modern React frontends. Offers a useful set of abstractions that prevent manually writing useEffect calls, helping eliminate possible sources of error. Maintained by Vercel. More info

name: Webpack 5
description: A very widely used free and open source module bundler for Javascript. Creates a dependency graph from a project and performs code-splitting to turn it into modules. Has a wide ecosystem of useful plugins for configuring support for languages, files, frameworks, style libraries etc. Also has a dev server useful for project development. More info.

name: Angular
description: Widely used frontend framework supported by Google. Built on TypeScript and favours a batteries-included approach with a number of Angular-specific libraries and tooling. Well supported, but as of 2021, it is trending in a negative direction on the State of JS Survey. More info

name: Styled Components
description: CSS-in-JS library to create custom components with styles applied to them at the JS level. Facilitates direct coupling of styles and application logic, as well as creating reusable styles outside of a traditional stylesheet. More info.

name: React Native
description: Create native apps for Android, iOS and more using React. Use react primitives render to native platform UI. Can interact with native code and APIs via Reacts declarative UI paradigm and JavaScript. A rich toolset. More info.

name: NPM 8
description: A widely used package manager for JavaScript. Supports Workspaces for splitting projects into sub-projects. More info.

name: yup
description: Runtime object schema definer and validator. More info.

name: react-hook-form
description: A form helper library for React using Hooks which offers helpers for form & schema validation, form state, error handling, integrating with app state, form integration and preventing unnecessary re-renders. Helps take the pain out of forms, similar to a library such as Formik. More info.

name: Clean-CSS
description: A CSS optimiser for node.js and any modern browser for tasks such as minifying, optimising properties, merging media queries, etc. More info

name: Mobx
description: A framework-agnostic state management framework for JavaScript based on functional reactive programming. Defines state which is observable, updated using actions, with UI being a derivation of state. More info.

name: SwiperJS
description: Free and Open Source mobile touch slider with hardware-accelerated transitions and native behaviour, designed for modern apps. Library agnostic, with a rich API. More info

name: React Router
description: A very widely used tool for handling page routing within React applications. Leverages the Link component within React code to provide navigation within a react Single Page App. Contains functionality for dealing with routing issues such as URL parameters, browser navigation and incorrect URLS. More info.

name: Classnames
description: A simple tool for conditionally joining CSS class names together, rather than using template literal conditional statements or manual string joining. More info.

name: Lodash
description: A very widely used utility library for JavaScript including many convenience functions for data transformation, math, language assertions and others. More info. Originally arose from JavaScript's lack of native functionality, however as the language has improved many features are now native, check You don't (may not) need Lodash/Underscore for more details and possible native alternatives.
